newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: FEATURE-SAFRICA'S HOUSING PROMISES BALANCE ON A KNIFE-EDGE.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE-SAFRICA'S HOUSING PROMISES BALANCE ON A KNIFE-EDGE.

text.p: Tourist brochures tout South Africa as a land of contrasts, but few countries display such huge differences between rich and poor and nowhere is the yawning gap more visible than in the country's housing.
In Johannesburg the mansions of the well-off Hyde Park area nestle just a few kilometres (miles) away from the ramshackle hovels of the township of Alexandra.
The disparity is so great that while foreign professionals are tempted to the country by the promise of a high-quality lifestyle, more than a fifth of all South Africans live in a shack or a hut.
Nearly half have neither electricity nor a modern toilet.
"There are still too many people who have to sleep out in the cold, on pavements, under bridges or in shacks,'' says Housing Minister Sankie Mthembi-Mahanyele.
A MILLION HOUSES PROMISED, PROGRESS AT SNAIL'S PACE

When it came to power in 1994 after decades of white minority rule, the African National Congress (ANC) was committed to providing a million houses in five years, aimed specifically at the poorest people.
But in the two and a half years since those heady election days, the plan has drawn criticism for the snail's pace of progress.
Statistics from the Department of Housing show that only 30,000 low-cost houses have actually been built so far.
One of the main problems has been a reluctance by banks to stump up cash to supplement subsidies from the government.
The largest subsidy of 15,000 rand ($3,200) is available to households that earn less than 800 rand a month. This drops to 5,000 rand for households bringing in between 2,501 and 3,500 rand.
But many banks see lending top-up sums to low-income households as a risk they are unwilling to take on.
This is heightened by a hangover of the "culture of non-payment'' from the apartheid era when withholding rent and debt payments was used as a tool against the racist state.

"Until a climate is fully established where contractual obligations are regarded as binding...it is always going to be a difficult market,'' said Duncan Reekie, divisional general manager for home loans at Standard Bank.

This means many of the lowest-income families are left with a mere 15,000 rand to buy a property, likely to be little more than a strip of land with a concrete base and a toilet -- a so-called serviced site.
"Those who get 15,000 rand cannot get loans so they can only afford a serviced site and maybe a tiny top structure,'' said Sharon Lewis of housing consultancy Settlement Dynamics.
There have been disputes between government and the private sector. Mthembi-Mahanyele has slammed local business.

Without naming names, he told reporters that one European group wishing to set up a plant to make parts for low-cost homes was told by the managing director of a major South African building firm that they were "wasting their time''.
Another problem has been the sometimes poor standard of construction. Land can be unsuitable, workmanship shoddy and some contractors will try to cut costs.
"The low-cost housing sector has a lot of risk for the developers and so they try to minimise expenses,'' Lewis said.
SOME GROUNDS FOR OPTIMISM
But things are not all doom and gloom and many say there are grounds for optimism.
Aside from the 30,000 homes built, there are 139,000 more at some stage of production and a further 56,000 are in the planning phase. Also a total of 372,000 subsidies have been released so far.
Many say the million-home target -- vital to an ANC government desperate to provide concrete benefits for its black supporters -- will still be reached.

The nature of the construction industry is such that projects take a long time to feed through the pipeline. Settlement Dynamics estimates most housing developments take two to three years before homes open for their new owners.
This means projects begun in 1995 should start to come through this year. Mthembi-Mahanyele has confidently declared 1997 as the first year of delivery for mass low-cost housing.
"We are on track to meet the commitment (of a million new homes) made during the election,'' a Department of Housing spokeswoman said.
There are also signs that the banks may become more willing to adopt a more relaxed approach.

Standard Bank, rare in being singled out by Mthembi-Mahanyele for praise, has adopted a policy of considering sympathetically loan applications from people who can show their payment records were adversely hit by the political situation before 1994 -- such as rent boycotts.
Reekie said there were opportunities for banks in low-cost housing, especially in tandem with government agencies that will provide cover for banks lending to the sector.
"We are looking at areas where new low-cost houses are being built and trying to find opportunities where lending can take place,'' Leekie said.
But he added that South Africa's interest rates -- raised to 20.25 percent in November -- needed to come down soon.
Economists add the government needs to muster the courage to act decisively to end the last vestiges of the culture of non-payment -- a policy they encouraged during the struggle.
"This really tests their political will,'' said David Galloway, group economist at Investec bank.

Settlement Dynamics hopes that 1997 will see the start of a housing boom. This would start a virtuous circle of creating jobs that allow more people to afford houses and so cut risks to banks and free more capital to build houses.
"There is a perception problem. People will hopefully see 1997 as the year when things take off,'' Lewis said.
